The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant with soft crepitus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 18,100/mm3
Platelet count 216,000/mm3
Serum
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 41 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 19 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 110 U/L
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Albumin 4.1 g/dL
Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant shows a gallbladder with an air-filled, thickened wall and no stones in the lumen. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Emphysematous cholecystitis.

Rationale: acute RUQ pain with fever, leukocytosis, hypotension in an older diabetic man plus ultrasound showing intramural/gallbladder gas (and crepitus) without stones is characteristic of gas-forming bacterial infection of the gallbladder.

question: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Reason: In patients with AIDS and CD4 <50/mm3, CMV causes painless vision loss with characteristic granular, yellow‑white perivascular (fluffy) lesions and dot‑blot retinal hemorrhages (“pizza‑pie” fundus). Ocular toxoplasmosis more often causes a focal necrotizing retinochoroiditis with marked vitritis (“headlight in the fog”), which is a different picture.

question: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Reasoning: In an AIDS patient with CD4 count <50/mm3, painless progressive vision loss and floaters, and fundoscopic "pizza‑pie" appearance — granular, yellow‑white perivascular retinal opacities with numerous dot‑blot hemorrhages — are classic for CMV retinitis. Toxoplasma, HSV/VZV necrotizing retinitis, and fungal endophthalmitis have different patterns (more focal necrosis with vitritis, painful/rapid peripheral necrosis, or systemic fungal signs) and are less consistent with this presentation. Treatment is systemic ganciclovir/valganciclovir (or intravitreal therapy) after diagnosis.

question: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.  

Reason: He has advanced AIDS (CD4 36/mm3), painless progressive vision loss with floaters/“black spots,” and the fundus shows perivascular granular yellow‑white lesions with dot‑blot hemorrhages — the classic “pizza‑pie/ketchup and cottage cheese” appearance of CMV retinitis. Other causes (toxoplasma, HSV/VZV necrotizing retinitis/PORN) have different exam features (prominent vitritis or rapidly confluent peripheral necrosis) that don’t match this presentation.

question: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Reasoning: CMV retinitis is the classic opportunistic infection in AIDS patients with CD4 <50 and presents with painless, progressive vision loss and floaters. Fundoscopy typically shows perivascular granular, yellow‑white retinal lesions with numerous dot‑blot hemorrhages ("pizza‑pie" appearance), exactly as described. Ocular toxoplasmosis more often causes focal necrotizing retinitis with intense vitritis ("headlight in fog") and adjacent chorioretinal scars, which is less consistent with this presentation.

question: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis — classic in AIDS with CD4 <50, causing painless vision loss/floaters and granular perivascular retinal lesions with dot‑blot hemorrhages.

question: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. She is also having difficulty holding things with her right hand. She denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which she takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. She has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. Her blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but her higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. Her gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. She has difficulty performing skilled movements with her right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with her index finger. She is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Correct — this presentation is most consistent with dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome from a lacunar infarct (left-sided pontine/internal capsule small-vessel infarct). 

Reasoning: sudden dysarthria with clumsiness and mild weakness of the right hand, preserved sensation and higher cortical functions, normal CT (early ischemia), and vascular risk factors point to a small deep (lacunar) infarct affecting corticobulbar/corticospinal fibers. The contralateral (left) lesion produces the right-sided signs.

question: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. She is also having difficulty holding things with her right hand. She denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which she takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. She has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. Her blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but her higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. Her gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. She has difficulty performing skilled movements with her right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with her index finger. She is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely: an acute left cortical (dominant-hemisphere) MCA territory infarct — superior-division (lateral frontal/parietal) stroke.

Reasoning: the patient has a contralateral central (UMN) facial palsy with preserved forehead wrinkling, contralateral hand weakness and ideomotor apraxia (difficulty with skilled movements/writing, trouble reaching visually), and dysarthria with mild corticobulbar involvement (weak gag). Sensation and extraocular movements are intact and there are no vestibular/brainstem signs (no vertigo, nystagmus, or ipsilateral pain/temp loss), which argues strongly against a lateral medullary (Wallenberg) brainstem lesion. A CT can be normal early in ischemic cortical stroke.

question: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. She is also having difficulty holding things with her right hand. She denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which she takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. She has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. Her blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but her higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. Her gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. She has difficulty performing skilled movements with her right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with her index finger. She is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
No — the most likely diagnosis is an acute ischemic stroke of the left cerebral cortex (left MCA territory affecting the precentral/postcentral region), not lateral medullary syndrome.

Reasoning: contralateral (right-sided) lower facial weakness with forehead sparing is an upper motor neuron (cortical) facial palsy implicating the left hemisphere. Right hand weakness with impaired skilled movements (apraxia) and dysarthria point to cortical motor and parietal involvement. Intact extraocular movements, preserved sensation, and a normal head CT early are all inconsistent with a lateral medullary (Wallenberg) brainstem lesion but fit an acute cortical (MCA) infarct.

question: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. She is also having difficulty holding things with her right hand. She denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which she takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. She has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. Her blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but her higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. Her gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. She has difficulty performing skilled movements with her right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with her index finger. She is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Conclusion: Dysarthria–clumsy hand syndrome (a lacunar infarct, most likely in the basis pontis or posterior limb of the internal capsule).

Reasoning: The acute dysarthria with a mild contralateral clumsy/weak hand (impaired skilled movements, mild weakness) and a central facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling fits the classic lacunar DCHS picture. Extraocular movements, gait, sensation and higher cortical function are preserved, and CT can be normal early — all typical for a small deep infarct in a patient with HTN/diabetes. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) would produce prominent vertigo, nystagmus, severe dysphagia/hoarseness, ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss and contralateral body sensory loss, which are absent here.

question: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. She is also having difficulty holding things with her right hand. She denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which she takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. She has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. Her blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but her higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. Her gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. She has difficulty performing skilled movements with her right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with her index finger. She is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely an acute ischemic cortical stroke of the left parietal (dominant) hemisphere — classically the superior division of the left MCA.

Rationale: acute contralateral (right) face and hand UMN weakness with forehead sparing, dysarthria, ideomotor apraxia (difficulty with skilled hand movements), and impaired visually guided reaching (optic ataxia) localize to the left parietal/cortical region. Normal CT early does not exclude ischemic stroke.

question: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach, 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury (sprain/tear) of the left knee.

Reasoning: A blow from the lateral side produces a valgus stress to the knee, causing MCL injury. Findings match an MCL lesion — medial joint‑line tenderness and medial laxity with valgus stress. A lateral collateral ligament injury would produce laxity with varus stress and lateral-sided tenderness, which are not present.

question: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach, 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely: An anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear — probably as part of the “unhappy triad” (ACL + medial collateral ligament + medial meniscus).

Reasoning: A lateral blow while the foot is planted produces valgus + rotational force classically causing ACL injury (often with MCL and medial meniscal damage). The immediate inability to bear weight, concern about instability, and rapid swelling (hemarthrosis) point to ACL disruption; the medial joint–line tenderness and valgus laxity indicate concomitant medial meniscal and MCL involvement.

question: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach, 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
The most likely diagnosis is a left medial collateral ligament (MCL) sprain/tear.

Reasoning: being tackled from the left imposes a valgus force on the left knee (lateral blow), which classically injures the MCL. The exam shows medial joint–line tenderness and increased medial laxity with valgus stress — the hallmark findings of MCL injury. (ACL or meniscal injuries would produce different specific tests: Lachman/pivot shift for ACL, McMurray/locking for meniscus.)

question: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her coach, 30 minutes after injuring her left knee while playing field hockey. She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury.

Reason: being tackled from the left produces a valgus force on the left knee, and the exam shows medial joint–line tenderness and medial laxity with a valgus stress test. An LCL injury would present with lateral-sided pain and laxity to varus stress, not medial laxity.

She was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on her left leg since the accident. She fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury — acute MCL sprain/tear (likely a moderate–severe [grade II–III]) from a lateral blow causing valgus stress. Exam findings (medial joint‑line tenderness and valgus laxity) match MCL injury.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placenta previa.

Reasoning: Painless, bright-red vaginal bleeding in the third trimester with a soft, nontender uterus is classic for placenta previa (prior cesarean increases the risk). Uterine atony is a postpartum cause of hemorrhage (after delivery), and placental abruption would present with painful, tender, hypertonic uterus and often fetal compromise. Confirm with ultrasound.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placenta previa (probably marginal/low-lying).

Reasoning: classic presentation is painless, bright‑red third‑trimester bleeding with a soft, non‑tender uterus and intermittent spontaneous cessation. Her prior lower‑segment cesarean and multiparity increase the risk. Abruptio placentae would be painful with a tender, hypertonic uterus and fetal distress; vasa previa causes acute fetal compromise (bradycardia/exsanguination) typically after membrane rupture; cervical lesions or bloody show are less likely to produce a sudden profuse bright‑red gush that then ceases.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placenta previa.

Reasoning: sudden, painless bright-red antepartum bleeding in the third trimester with a soft, non‑tender uterus and preserved fetal heart rate is classic for placenta previa. Risk factors (multiparity, prior cesarean) increase likelihood. Abruptio placentae would be painful with a tender/firm uterus and fetal distress; vasa previa presents with fetal bradycardia after membrane rupture. Ultrasound is needed to confirm and digital vaginal exam should be avoided.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
No — the most likely diagnosis is placenta previa.

Reasoning: This is painless, bright-red vaginal bleeding in the third trimester with a soft, nontender uterus and intermittent bleeding that can stop and start — classic for placenta previa. Uterine atony causes postpartum hemorrhage after delivery when the uterus fails to contract, not antepartum bleeding. Vasa previa would produce fetal heart rate abnormalities; abruption is painful with a tender, contracted uterus.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. She has had no prenatal care. Her third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; her first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Placenta previa — painless, bright-red third-trimester bleeding with a soft, non-tender uterus and intermittent bleeding (and a history of prior cesarean, a risk factor) is most consistent with placenta previa.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. The patient reports that he first noticed the lesion 6 months ago, when he thought it was a pimple. He denies any antecedent trauma to the area. Of note, the patient works as a parking lot attendant and has a history of 2 basal cell carcinomas on his neck that were previously excised. On exam, his temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
truth: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
response: Correct — this is most consistent with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, which commonly invades locally and can spread to regional (cutaneous) lymph nodes but only uncommonly gives distant metastases. Reason: sun-exposed site with ulceration and typical histology (keratin pearls/intercellular bridges) links to actinic damage/actinic keratoses → SCC, which has higher nodal than hematogenous metastatic risk.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. The patient reports that he first noticed the lesion 6 months ago, when he thought it was a pimple. He denies any antecedent trauma to the area. Of note, the patient works as a parking lot attendant and has a history of 2 basal cell carcinomas on his neck that were previously excised. On exam, his temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
truth: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
response:
Conclusion: This is cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (not basal cell carcinoma) — most characteristically associated with keratin pearls and intercellular bridges and with chronic UV/actinic damage (actinic keratoses) and a risk of regional lymph node metastasis.

Reasoning: An enlarging scaly, ulcerating lesion on a sun‑exposed forehead in an older patient fits SCC; histology of SCC shows keratinization (keratin pearls) and desmosomal intercellular bridges rather than the palisading nuclei seen in basal cell carcinoma.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. The patient reports that he first noticed the lesion 6 months ago, when he thought it was a pimple. He denies any antecedent trauma to the area. Of note, the patient works as a parking lot attendant and has a history of 2 basal cell carcinomas on his neck that were previously excised. On exam, his temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
truth: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
response:
Conclusion: This is squamous cell carcinoma — most associated with keratin pearls on histology and with antecedent actinic keratoses from chronic sun (UV) exposure. 

Reasoning: The lesion is a scaly, enlarging ulcerating plaque on sun‑exposed forehead in an older, outdoor worker — classic for SCC. Histology of SCC shows keratinization (keratin pearls) and intercellular bridges; SCC is linked to actinic damage, HPV (mucosal sites), arsenic exposure, and has a higher metastatic risk than BCC.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
truth: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
response:
Conclusion: This is squamous cell carcinoma — it commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes but rarely gives distant metastases.

Reasoning: The clinical picture (ulcerating, enlarging lesion on sun‑exposed forehead in an older man with chronic sun exposure) plus histology consistent with squamous differentiation (keratin pearls/intercellular bridges) fits SCC. Palisading nuclei describe basal cell carcinoma, which is different and rarely metastasizes at all.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. The patient reports that he first noticed the lesion 6 months ago, when he thought it was a pimple. He denies any antecedent trauma to the area. Of note, the patient works as a parking lot attendant and has a history of 2 basal cell carcinomas on his neck that were previously excised. On exam, his temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
truth: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
response: The lesion is a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma — classically associated with chronic sun (UV) damage/actinic (solar) keratoses with UV‑induced p53 mutations, and it has a higher risk of metastasis to regional lymph nodes.

question: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician. The man has been feeling very tired lately and thinks that he looks more pale. The physician orders a complete blood count, which shows: Hgb 8.5 g/dL; WBC 1,200/microliter; platelets 70,000/microliter. The patient is referred for bone marrow biopsy, which shows the findings in Figure A. What is the correct diagnosis?
response:
The correct diagnosis is aplastic anemia (bone marrow aplasia).  

Reason: the patient has pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia) and the biopsy in this setting classically shows a markedly hypocellular marrow with fatty replacement and absence of blasts or malignant infiltration — findings inconsistent with acute myelogenous leukemia, which would show a hypercellular marrow packed with myeloblasts (>20% blasts).

question: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician. The man has been feeling very tired lately and thinks that he looks more pale. The physician orders a complete blood count, which shows: Hgb 8.5 g/dL; WBC 1,200/microliter; platelets 70,000/microliter. The patient is referred for bone marrow biopsy, which shows the findings in Figure A. What is the correct diagnosis?
response:
Correct diagnosis: Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia with a bone marrow biopsy showing sheets of myeloblasts (often with Auer rods and myeloperoxidase positivity) meeting the diagnostic threshold of >20% blasts. This fits AML. CML would classically present with marked leukocytosis with a granulocytic left shift, basophilia and splenomegaly rather than pancytopenia and marrow packed with blasts.

question: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician. The man has been feeling very tired lately and thinks that he looks more pale. The physician orders a complete blood count, which shows: Hgb 8.5 g/dL; WBC 1,200/microliter; platelets 70,000/microliter. The patient is referred for bone marrow biopsy, which shows the findings in Figure A. What is the correct diagnosis?
response:
Correct diagnosis: aplastic anemia.

Reasoning: the patient has pancytopenia (low Hgb, WBC, platelets) and the bone marrow biopsy in this setting shows hypocellular marrow with fatty (adipose) replacement and markedly decreased hematopoietic elements — findings characteristic of aplastic anemia rather than leukemias (which produce hypercellular marrow with blasts or granulocytic hyperplasia).

question: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician. The man has been feeling very tired lately and thinks that he looks more pale. The physician orders a complete blood count, which shows: Hgb 8.5 g/dL; WBC 1,200/microliter; platelets 70,000/microliter. The patient is referred for bone marrow biopsy, which shows the findings in Figure A. What is the correct diagnosis?
response:
Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia (anemia, severe neutropenia, thrombocytopenia) and the marrow biopsy demonstrates a predominance of myeloblasts (often with Auer rods) consistent with AML. CML would typically present with marked leukocytosis and granulocytic hyperplasia with few blasts in the chronic phase, not the cytopenias and blast-filled marrow seen here.

question: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician. The man has been feeling very tired lately and thinks that he looks more pale. The physician orders a complete blood count, which shows: Hgb 8.5 g/dL; WBC 1,200/microliter; platelets 70,000/microliter. The patient is referred for bone marrow biopsy, which shows the findings in Figure A. What is the correct diagnosis?
response: Aplastic anemia (bone marrow failure) — pancytopenia with a hypocellular, fatty (“empty”) marrow on biopsy consistent with marrow aplasia.

question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. He also has been sweaty, short of breath, and nauseous, but denies cough, fever, vomiting, or a history of trauma. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day since age 15, and currently takes lisonopril, amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. In the ED, his temperature is 98.5 deg F (36.9 deg C), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is seen in Figure A and appears similar to an EKG obtained 1 month ago. He appears to be in moderate distress. Auscultation of his chest revealed no murmurs and his lungs are clear bilaterally. There is no tenderness to palpation along his chest wall. His abdominal exam is noteworthy for a pulsatile mass. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?
response:
Conclusion: The most likely cause is a ruptured (or leaking) abdominal aortic aneurysm causing acute retroperitoneal hemorrhage — not costochondritis.

Why: classic triad of sudden severe back/abdominal pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass in an older male smoker points to AAA rupture. EKG unchanged from baseline and clear lungs make MI/heart failure unlikely; pain is not reproducible with chest-wall palpation (so not costochondritis). This is a surgical emergency requiring rapid resuscitation and emergent vascular/operative management.

question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. He also has been sweaty, short of breath, and nauseous, but denies cough, fever, vomiting, or a history of trauma. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day since age 15, and currently takes lisonopril, amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. In the ED, his temperature is 98.5 deg F (36.9 deg C), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is seen in Figure A and appears similar to an EKG obtained 1 month ago. He appears to be in moderate distress. Auscultation of his chest revealed no murmurs and his lungs are clear bilaterally. There is no tenderness to palpation along his chest wall. His abdominal exam is noteworthy for a pulsatile mass. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?
response:
Most likely: acute aortic dissection (intimal tear of the proximal aorta — Stanford type A) rather than a ruptured AAA.

Reasoning: sudden, severe “tearing/sharp” chest pain radiating to the back in an older hypertensive smoker is classic for aortic dissection. Hypotension and tachycardia can reflect extension with hemorrhage or pericardial tamponade. The normal/unchanged ECG argues against acute MI. The pulsatile abdominal mass likely represents a preexisting AAA but does not explain acute chest‑onset pain; dissections can originate in the ascending aorta and propagate distally. Immediate BP/heart‑rate control and urgent imaging (CTA chest/abdomen or TEE) with vascular/cardiothoracic surgery consult are indicated.

question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. He also has been sweaty, short of breath, and nauseous, but denies cough, fever, vomiting, or a history of trauma. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?
response:
Conclusion: Rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) due to atherosclerotic degeneration of the aortic wall.

Reasoning: Sudden severe pain radiating to the back with hypotension and a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass is classic for AAA rupture. His age, long smoking history, hypertension and hypercholesterolemia predispose to atherosclerotic aneurysm formation. The unchanged ECG makes acute MI less likely; clear lungs and lack of chest wall tenderness argue against PE or musculoskeletal causes. AAA rupture is a surgical emergency explaining his presentation.

question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?
response:
Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Reasoning: his sudden severe chest/back pain, hypotension and tachycardia, diaphoresis, strong risk factors (age, long-term smoking, HTN), and a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass are classic for a leaking/ruptured AAA. Costochondritis would produce focal, reproducible chest‑wall tenderness and normal hemodynamics and would not explain a pulsatile abdominal mass or shock. This is a surgical emergency.

question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. He also has been sweaty, short of breath, and nauseous, but denies cough, fever, vomiting, or a history of trauma. In the ED, his temperature is 98.5 deg F (36.9 deg C), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is seen in Figure A and appears similar to an EKG obtained 1 month ago. He appears to be in moderate distress. Auscultation of his chest revealed no murmurs and his lungs are clear bilaterally. There is no tenderness to palpation along his chest wall. His abdominal exam is noteworthy for a pulsatile mass. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?
response:
Rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm from atherosclerotic weakening of the aortic wall.  
(History of sudden severe back-radiating pain, hypotension and a pulsatile abdominal mass with a nonischemic EKG is classic for ruptured AAA.)

question:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of abdominal distention, yellow coloring of the skin, and dark urine. He also reports malaise and progressive shortness of breath, associated with slight exertion, for several weeks. The patient is a chronic drinker, and he was diagnosed with cirrhosis 2 years ago. He was warned to stop drinking alcohol, but he continues to drink. He hasn’t accepted any more testing and has refused to visit the doctor until now. His vital signs are heart rate 62/min, respiratory rate 26/min, temperature 37.4°C (99.3°F), and blood pressure 117/95 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is dyspnea and polypnea. Skin and sclera are jaundiced. The abdomen has visible collateral circulation and looks distended. There is diffuse abdominal pain upon palpation in the right hemiabdomen, and the liver is palpated 10 cm below the right costal border. The legs show significant edema. CT scan shows cirrhosis with portal hypertension and collateral circulation. During the fifth day of his hospital stay, the patient presents with oliguria and altered mental status. Laboratory studies show:
  Day 1
Day 5
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
11.2 g/dL

  Negative for nitrite

0–1 WBC per high power field
No evidence of casts or proteinuria
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s increased creatinine?
response:
Most likely cause: hepatorenal syndrome — functional (pre-renal) renal failure from advanced cirrhosis.

Reasoning: He has end‑stage liver disease with progressive jaundice, ascites/portal hypertension and new oliguria with a rising creatinine but a bland urinalysis (no pyuria, hematuria, casts or proteinuria). That pattern (rapid renal deterioration in cirrhosis with no evidence of intrinsic renal or urinary tract infection) is characteristic of hepatorenal syndrome due to splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction. Pyelonephritis would produce fever, flank pain and pyuria/positive urine nitrite or leukocyte esterase, which this patient lacks.

Why: he has decompensated cirrhosis with large-volume ascites/portal hypertension, progressive rise in creatinine to >2.5 mg/dL over a short interval, oliguria and altered mentation, and a bland urine sediment (no RBCs/WBCs, no casts, no proteinuria) — all classic for hepatorenal syndrome (renal hypoperfusion from splanchnic vasodilation with intense renal vasoconstriction). Intrinsic renal causes (ATN, glomerulonephritis, interstitial nephritis) would usually show abnormal urine sediment or proteinuria; postrenal obstruction would show hydronephrosis on imaging. Pre-renal azotemia would generally improve with volume expansion. These features make HRS the best fit.

question:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of abdominal distention, yellow coloring of the skin, and dark urine. He also reports malaise and progressive shortness of breath, associated with slight exertion, for several weeks. The patient is a chronic drinker, and he was diagnosed with cirrhosis 2 years ago. He was warned to stop drinking alcohol, but he continues to drink. He hasn’t accepted any more testing and has refused to visit the doctor until now. His vital signs are heart rate 62/min, respiratory rate 26/min, temperature 37.4°C (99.3°F), and blood pressure 117/95 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is dyspnea and polypnea. Skin and sclera are jaundiced. The abdomen has visible collateral circulation and looks distended. There is diffuse abdominal pain upon palpation in the right hemiabdomen, and the liver is palpated 10 cm below the right costal border. The legs show significant edema. Why: he has decompensated cirrhosis with ascites/portal hypertension, progressive rise in creatinine with oliguria and altered mental status, and a bland urinalysis (no hematuria, protein, leukocytes or casts) arguing against intrinsic renal disease or UTI. This pattern (renal failure in setting of severe liver disease, without intrinsic kidney findings) is classic for hepatorenal syndrome.
