question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:
At birth Day 30
Hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL 15.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 6,830/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 2% 3%
Eosinophils 13% 10%
Lymphocytes 60% 63%
Monocytes 25% 24%
Platelet count 220,000/mm3 223,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: severe congenital neutropenia (Kostmann syndrome).

Reasoning: The infant has recurrent bacterial skin infection (impetigo) in the neonatal period with persistently very low absolute neutrophil counts (ANC ≈7600×0.02 ≈152/mm3 at birth and ≈6830×0.03 ≈205/mm3 on day 30), consistent with severe neutropenia (<500/mm3) present from birth. Cyclic neutropenia would show periodic fluctuations; disorders like CGD have normal neutrophil counts.

question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:
At birth Day 30
Hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL 15.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 6,830/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 2% 3%
Eosinophils 13% 10%
Lymphocytes 60% 63%
Monocytes 25% 24%
Platelet count 220,000/mm3 223,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: severe congenital neutropenia (Kostmann syndrome / congenital neutropenia).

Reasoning: her ANC is profoundly low at birth and at 1 month (≈150–200 cells/mm3), with otherwise normal platelets and red cells, and she already has recurrent bacterial skin infection (perioral impetigo). Diamond–Blackfan causes isolated anemia (red‑cell aplasia) with low hemoglobin/reticulocytes, not severe neutropenia. Congenital neutropenia presents early with severe bacterial infections and an ANC <500; management includes G‑CSF and infection control, with hematopoietic stem cell transplant for refractory cases.

question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:
At birth Day 30
Hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL 15.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 6,830/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 2% 3%
Eosinophils 13% 10%
Lymphocytes 60% 63%
Monocytes 25% 24%
Platelet count 220,000/mm3 223,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely severe congenital neutropenia (Kostmann syndrome).

Reasoning: the infant has persistent, profound neutropenia from birth (ANC ≈ 152 at birth and ≈ 205/mm3 at 30 days) and early bacterial skin infection (perioral impetigo). This pattern—severe neutropenia with recurrent bacterial infections in the neonatal period—is classic for congenital neutropenia. (Not Diamond‑Blackfan, which causes isolated macrocytic anemia rather than neutropenia.)

question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:
At birth Day 30
Hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL 15.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 6,830/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 2% 3%
Eosinophils 13% 10%
Lymphocytes 60% 63%
Monocytes 25% 24%
Platelet count 220,000/mm3 223,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Severe congenital neutropenia (eg, Kostmann syndrome).

Reasoning: The infant has recurrent bacterial skin infection (impetigo) and a persistently very low absolute neutrophil count (ANC ≈152 at birth and ≈205 on day 30), consistent with congenital severe neutropenia (ANC <500). Other cell lines and hemoglobin are essentially normal, which argues against Diamond–Blackfan (a congenital pure red-cell aplasia causing anemia and low reticulocytes).

question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:
At birth Day 30
Hemoglobin 18.0 g/dL 15.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,600/mm3 6,830/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 2% 3%
Eosinophils 13% 10%
Lymphocytes 60% 63%
Monocytes 25% 24%
Platelet count 220,000/mm3 223,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response: Atopic dermatitis (infantile eczema) — acute eczematous perioral lesions with peripheral eosinophilia; the honey‑colored crusts reflect secondary impetiginization.

question: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: parasagittal meningioma (dural-based meningioma).

Reasoning: The patient has progressive headaches, personality change, new seizures and focal UMN signs confined to the right lower extremity—localizing to the left medial frontal/parasagittal motor cortex (leg area). MRI of meningioma typically shows a well-circumscribed, dural-based enhancing mass often with a “dural tail.” Pituitary adenoma would produce visual field and endocrine findings rather than a focal contralateral leg paresis.

question: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: parasagittal meningioma.

Reasoning: the clinical picture (progressive headaches, new-onset seizures, personality change and an isolated upper-motor‑neuron deficit of the right leg/Babinski) localizes to the medial frontal/paracentral lobule (leg area) — a classic site for a parasagittal, dural‑based mass. On MRI a meningioma appears as a well‑circumscribed, extra‑axial lesion with a broad dural attachment (often a “dural tail”) that compresses cortex rather than originating within it. Intra‑axial gliomas (eg, oligodendroglioma) would arise in the parenchyma rather than show a dural‑based appearance.

question: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: a parasagittal (falcine) meningioma compressing the left paracentral lobule.

Reasoning: The subacute headaches, new seizures and personality change with a right-sided upper motor neuron pattern localized to the leg point to a left medial frontal/paracentral lesion. The MRI shows a well-circumscribed dural‑based mass along the falx with homogeneous enhancement/dural tail—classic for meningioma.

question: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
The most likely diagnosis is a parasagittal meningioma. 

Reasoning: focal UMN signs confined to the right lower extremity (spastic paresis, right Babinski) point to a left medial frontal/paracentral lobule lesion (leg area of motor cortex), which classically is caused by a dural-based parasagittal meningioma that produces headaches, personality change, and seizures. A pituitary adenoma localizes to the sella (causing visual field and endocrine findings), not focal contralateral leg spasticity.

question: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely a parasagittal meningioma (dural-based meningioma along the falx). 

Rationale: slow progressive headaches, personality change and new seizures over months with contralateral (right) lower-extremity pyramidal signs point to a medial frontal/parasagittal lesion compressing the medial precentral gyrus. Meningiomas are extra-axial, dural-based, homogeneously enhancing masses often with a “dural tail.”

question:
A 67-year-old woman presents to her oncologist for a followup appointment. She was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer 1 year ago, and had recent blood work that she wants to followup. The patient has a past medical history of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and bulimia nervosa. She recently broke her ankle when she fell down a flight of stairs. She is currently taking fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/77 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a lean woman in no acute distress with an ankle brace. Her exam is non-remarkable. Laboratory values are as seen below and in Figure A.

Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 7,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS).

Reasoning: an older asymptomatic patient with an M‑spike on protein electrophoresis but without CRAB features or cytopenias (Hgb 13, normal WBC/platelets, no reported renal failure or hypercalcemia) is most consistent with MGUS rather than multiple myeloma; smoldering myeloma would require higher M‑protein or ≥10% clonal plasma cells. Follow‑up monitoring (periodic SPEP, immunofixation, and clinical assessment) is indicated.

question:
A 67-year-old woman presents to her oncologist for a followup appointment. She was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer 1 year ago, and had recent blood work that she wants to followup. The patient has a past medical history of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and bulimia nervosa. She recently broke her ankle when she fell down a flight of stairs. She is currently taking fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/77 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a lean woman in no acute distress with an ankle brace. Her exam is non-remarkable. Laboratory values are as seen below and in Figure A.

Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 7,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS).

Reasoning: an older, asymptomatic patient being followed after cancer with normal CBC, no renal failure or hypercalcemia and only an isolated small M‑spike on SPEP (Figure A). MGUS is common in elderly and is defined by an M protein <3 g/dL, <10% clonal bone marrow plasma cells and no CRAB features (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions). Waldenström macroglobulinemia would be IgM‑predominant with hyperviscosity/constitutional features and lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, and multiple myeloma would usually show end‑organ damage (anemia, lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia or renal impairment), none of which are present here.

question:
A 67-year-old woman presents to her oncologist for a followup appointment. She was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer 1 year ago, and had recent blood work that she wants to followup. The patient has a past medical history of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and bulimia nervosa. She recently broke her ankle when she fell down a flight of stairs. She is currently taking fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/77 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a lean woman in no acute distress with an ankle brace. Her exam is non-remarkable. Laboratory values are as seen below and in Figure A.

Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 7,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS).

Reasoning: Figure A likely shows an isolated monoclonal (M) spike on serum protein electrophoresis in an otherwise asymptomatic 67‑year‑old with normal hemoglobin, platelets, and no clinical CRAB features (no anemia, renal failure, hypercalcemia, or lytic bone lesions attributable to plasma cell neoplasm). This fits MGUS rather than multiple myeloma (which would have end‑organ damage) or Waldenström macroglobulinemia (which is IgM‑related and presents with hyperviscosity symptoms). Follow‑up with periodic SPEP/clinical monitoring is indicated.

question:
A 67-year-old woman presents to her oncologist for a followup appointment. She was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer 1 year ago, and had recent blood work that she wants to followup. The patient has a past medical history of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and bulimia nervosa. She recently broke her ankle when she fell down a flight of stairs. She is currently taking fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/77 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a lean woman in no acute distress with an ankle brace. Her exam is non-remarkable. Laboratory values are as seen below and in Figure A.

Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 7,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS).

Reasoning: an older, asymptomatic patient with otherwise normal CBC and no signs of end‑organ damage (no hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, or lytic bone lesions) is most consistent with MGUS rather than symptomatic plasma‑cell dyscrasia. Waldenström macroglobulinemia would typically show IgM paraprotein with hyperviscosity symptoms and often anemia/constitutional findings; multiple myeloma would show CRAB features. Confirmation requires quantifying the M‑protein (SPEP/IFE), bone marrow plasma‑cell percentage (<10% for MGUS) and periodic monitoring.

question:
A 67-year-old woman presents to her oncologist for a followup appointment. She was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer 1 year ago, and had recent blood work that she wants to followup. The patient has a past medical history of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and bulimia nervosa. She recently broke her ankle when she fell down a flight of stairs. She is currently taking fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/77 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a lean woman in no acute distress with an ankle brace. Her exam is non-remarkable. Laboratory values are as seen below and in Figure A.

Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 7,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Osteoporosis (postmenopausal/secondary osteoporosis) causing a fragility fracture.

Rationale: 67‑year‑old postmenopausal woman with risk factors (age, low body weight/bulimia, prior breast cancer treatment that may worsen bone loss) with a low‑trauma fracture. CBC is normal and other labs/imaging (Figure A) are consistent with low bone mineral density (DEXA T‑score ≤ −2.5).

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: anterior spinal artery syndrome (ischemic anterior cord syndrome) from perioperative hypotension/hemorrhage.

Reason: she has bilateral loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation below the waist with preserved vibration/proprioception — classic for anterior two‑thirds cord dysfunction (corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts affected, dorsal columns spared). The large blood loss and hypotension make spinal cord ischemia likely; absent lower‑extremity reflexes reflect acute spinal shock. Brown‑Séquard (hemisection) would produce ipsilateral motor/proprioceptive loss and contralateral pain/temp loss, not the symmetric pattern seen here.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: anterior spinal artery (anterior cord) infarction causing spinal cord ischemia.

Reason: she has an abrupt paraplegia with loss of pain and temperature below a spinal level but preserved vibration/proprioception — classic spinothalamic and corticospinal dysfunction with spared dorsal columns seen in anterior spinal artery syndrome. The history of major hemorrhage and hypotension (postpartum blood loss/transfusion) predisposes to ischemia of the ASA (eg, watershed infarct in the lower thoracic cord/artery of Adamkiewicz). Other possibilities (cauda equina, transverse myelitis, spinal anesthesia block, Guillain-Barré) do not fit the pattern of a sensory level with selective loss of pain/temp and motor function with preserved vibration.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Yes — anterior spinal artery syndrome (ischemic infarction of the anterior spinal cord) is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: acute paraplegia with loss of pain and temperature below the waist but preserved vibration/proprioception (tuning-fork sensation) is classic for anterior cord (anterior 2/3) involvement. The history of massive blood loss and hypotension during delivery provides a mechanism for anterior spinal artery hypoperfusion/ischemia. Absent lower‑extremity reflexes early are consistent with spinal shock. Other possibilities (posterior cord syndrome, cauda equina, transverse myelitis, epidural hematoma) do not fit the selective loss of motor and spinothalamic modalities with intact dorsal-column function and the ischemic risk from hypovolemia.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
The most likely diagnosis is anterior spinal artery syndrome (anterior cord syndrome).

Reasoning: She has acute bilateral flaccid paralysis (0/5 strength, absent lower reflexes) with loss of pain and temperature below the waist but preserved vibration/proprioception — a pattern of anterior cord dysfunction because the anterior spinal artery supplies the motor tracts and spinothalamic tracts while sparing the dorsal columns. The setting of severe blood loss/hypotension makes ischemia of the anterior spinal artery most likely. Brown-Séquard (hemisection) would cause ipsilateral motor and proprioceptive loss with contralateral pain/temp loss, which does not match this bilateral presentation.

question: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Anterior spinal (anterior cord) syndrome from ischemic infarction of the anterior spinal artery — acute anterior cord ischemia after hypovolemia. It produces bilateral loss of motor function and pain/temperature below the lesion with preserved dorsal-column vibration/proprioception.

question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma.

Reasoning: Older patient with fatigue, weight loss, lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly, mild leukocytosis, and a positive direct Coombs test fits CLL, which commonly causes autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The peripheral smear in CLL typically shows a predominance of small mature-appearing lymphocytes and characteristic fragile "smudge" cells rather than blasts or Auer rods seen in acute myelogenous leukemia.

question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Reasoning: The patient is an older adult with painless, diffuse lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, a modest leukocytosis with predominant small mature-appearing lymphocytes on the peripheral smear (with characteristic “smudge” cells), and a positive direct antiglobulin test reflecting autoimmune hemolytic anemia — all classic features of CLL/SLL. Other B‑cell leukemias/lymphomas (eg, hairy cell leukemia, mantle cell) have different clinical/morphologic patterns (eg, massive splenomegaly without diffuse adenopathy for hairy cell) and are less consistent with this presentation.

question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Reasoning: Elderly patient with painless, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, lymphocytosis, a positive direct Coombs (autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a known complication of CLL), and the peripheral smear classically showing many small mature lymphocytes with smudge cells — all features most consistent with CLL rather than acute leukemias or other lymphomas.

question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Reasoning: The patient is an elderly man with indolent systemic symptoms, diffuse non‑tender lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, mild anemia with leukocytosis, a positive direct Coombs test (AI hemolytic anemia is a known CLL complication), and the smear in this setting would show many small, mature‑appearing lymphocytes and characteristic "smudge" cells. Acute myelogenous leukemia would present with numerous blasts (often Auer rods), more acute illness and cytopenias rather than this chronic lymphocytosis and lymphadenopathy.

question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) — the smear likely shows numerous small mature lymphocytes with smudge cells, and CLL in elderly patients often presents with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and Coombs-positive autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

question: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of HIV presents to the emergency department with a rash. He states that it has been gradually worsening over the past week thus prompting his presentation. The patient works outdoors in construction and is poorly compliant with his medications. His vitals are notable for a low-grade fever. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
response:
Conclusion: Bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella (most commonly B. henselae). 

Reasoning: In an immunocompromised HIV patient with low‑grade fever and rapidly progressive friable red–purple vascular papules/nodules (Figure A), the presentation is classic for bacillary angiomatosis, caused by Bartonella species (B. henselae from cats; B. quintana from body lice). It mimics Kaposi sarcoma clinically but has neutrophilic inflammation on histology and responds to macrolides or doxycycline.

question: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of HIV presents to the emergency department with a rash. He states that it has been gradually worsening over the past week thus prompting his presentation. The patient works outdoors in construction and is poorly compliant with his medications. His vitals are notable for a low-grade fever. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
response:
Most likely: Kaposi sarcoma from human herpesvirus 8 (HHV‑8) infection — not basal cell carcinoma.

Reasoning: In an HIV patient nonadherent to ART, violaceous/erythematous multifocal papules or nodules that develop over days–weeks with low‑grade systemic symptoms are classic for Kaposi sarcoma. KS is a vascular spindle‑cell tumor driven by HHV‑8; biopsy shows spindle cells, slitlike vascular spaces, extravasated RBCs and hemosiderin, and is HHV‑8 positive on immunostain. Basal cell carcinoma is typically a solitary pearly telangiectatic lesion in older sun‑exposed patients and is not associated with systemic fever or multifocal violaceous lesions in immunosuppression.  

Confirm with skin biopsy and HHV‑8 testing; treat by optimizing ART (and local/systemic therapy as indicated).

question: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of HIV presents to the emergency department with a rash. He states that it has been gradually worsening over the past week thus prompting his presentation. The patient works outdoors in construction and is poorly compliant with his medications. His vitals are notable for a low-grade fever. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
response:
Most likely Bacillary angiomatosis from Bartonella henselae. 

Reason: In an HIV patient noncompliant with ART, fever plus rapidly developing friable red vascular papules/plaques suggests bacillary angiomatosis (Bartonella spp. infection) rather than Kaposi sarcoma (HHV‑8), which is typically violaceous and less febrile. Histology shows lobular capillary proliferation with neutrophils and organisms on Warthin‑Starry stain; treated with macrolides or doxycycline.

question: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of HIV presents to the emergency department with a rash. He states that it has been gradually worsening over the past week thus prompting his presentation. The patient works outdoors in construction and is poorly compliant with his medications. His vitals are notable for a low-grade fever. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Bartonella henselae infection causing bacillary angiomatosis.

Reasoning: In an HIV-positive, medication-noncompliant patient with systemic symptoms and rapidly progressive multiple erythematous vascular papules/nodules, bacillary angiomatosis is classic — vascular, friable lesions with low‑grade fever. Basal cell carcinoma is usually solitary, slow-growing, non‑febrile, and not typical in this presentation. Diagnosis is supported by biopsy with neutrophilic infiltrate and organisms on Warthin‑Starry stain; treat with erythromycin or doxycycline.

question: A 44-year-old man with a past medical history of HIV presents to the emergency department with a rash. He states that it has been gradually worsening over the past week thus prompting his presentation. The patient works outdoors in construction and is poorly compliant with his medications. His vitals are notable for a low-grade fever. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
response: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV‑8) infection causing Kaposi sarcoma — a vascular, spindle‑cell proliferation that produces violaceous cutaneous lesions in immunocompromised (HIV) patients.

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision at 25 miles per hour. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary and secondary survey are performed and are only notable for bruising along her chest wall bilaterally. An initial pelvic radiograph, an electrocardiogram (ECG) are performed and are unremarkable. A chest radiograph is performed and is notable for a sternal fracture and several rib fractures. The patient is given morphine and her heart rate subsequently improves to 80/min. The patient is observed in the emergency department over the next 6 hours and her laboratory values and a repeat ECG return within normal limits. The patient suddenly complains of shortness of breath. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. A repeat chest radiograph is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: pulmonary contusion.

Reasoning: blunt chest trauma with sternal and rib fractures followed by delayed dyspnea, tachypnea/tachycardia and hypoxemia several hours after injury is classic for pulmonary contusion. CXR in contusion shows new, patchy, nonlobar alveolar opacities that develop/worsen over hours (unlike an immediate pneumothorax, which shows a pleural line and absent peripheral markings).

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision at 25 miles per hour. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary and secondary survey are performed and are only notable for bruising along her chest wall bilaterally. An initial pelvic radiograph, an electrocardiogram (ECG) are performed and are unremarkable. A chest radiograph is performed and is notable for a sternal fracture and several rib fractures. The patient is given morphine and her heart rate subsequently improves to 80/min. The patient is observed in the emergency department over the next 6 hours and her laboratory values and a repeat ECG return within normal limits. The patient suddenly complains of shortness of breath. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. A repeat chest radiograph is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: pulmonary contusion.

Reasoning: blunt chest trauma with sternal and rib fractures commonly produces pulmonary contusion that may be radiographically occult initially and then evolve over hours, presenting with new dyspnea, hypoxemia and tachypnea and patchy alveolar/air‑space opacities on the repeat chest x‑ray. Cardiac contusion is unlikely here because the ECG and labs were normal and there are no arrhythmias, tamponade signs, or persistent hemodynamic instability. A pneumothorax or large hemothorax would have different radiographic features (pleural line/absent markings or layering opacification and mediastinal shift/hypotension), and an acute PE is much less likely so soon after injury and would usually have a normal chest x‑ray.

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision at 25 miles per hour. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary and secondary survey are performed and are only notable for bruising along her chest wall bilaterally. An initial pelvic radiograph, an electrocardiogram (ECG) are performed and are unremarkable. A chest radiograph is performed and is notable for a sternal fracture and several rib fractures. The patient is given morphine and her heart rate subsequently improves to 80/min. The patient is observed in the emergency department over the next 6 hours and her laboratory values and a repeat ECG return within normal limits. The patient suddenly complains of shortness of breath. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. A repeat chest radiograph is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely a traumatic pneumothorax (delayed pneumothorax from rib fractures).

Reason: sudden dyspnea, tachycardia and hypoxia hours after blunt chest trauma with rib fractures, and the repeat chest x‑ray would show a pleural (visceral) line with absent peripheral lung markings consistent with a pneumothorax. Cardiac contusion is less likely given normal ECG/labs and the radiographic finding.

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision at 25 miles per hour. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary and secondary survey are performed and are only notable for bruising along her chest wall bilaterally. An initial pelvic radiograph, an electrocardiogram (ECG) are performed and are unremarkable. A chest radiograph is performed and is notable for a sternal fracture and several rib fractures. The patient is given morphine and her heart rate subsequently improves to 80/min. The patient is observed in the emergency department over the next 6 hours and her laboratory values and a repeat ECG return within normal limits. The patient suddenly complains of shortness of breath. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. A repeat chest radiograph is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Pulmonary contusion.

Reason: Blunt chest trauma with sternal/rib fractures plus delayed (hours) onset dyspnea, hypoxemia and tachypnea with a new patchy, nonlobar infiltrate on chest x‑ray is classic for pulmonary contusion (alveolar hemorrhage/edema that may be radiographically delayed). Normal ECG and labs argue against cardiac contusion; a pneumothorax would show a pleural line/collapsed lung and different exam findings.

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision at 25 miles per hour. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 127/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary and secondary survey are performed and are only notable for bruising along her chest wall bilaterally. An initial pelvic radiograph, an electrocardiogram (ECG) are performed and are unremarkable. A chest radiograph is performed and is notable for a sternal fracture and several rib fractures. The patient is given morphine and her heart rate subsequently improves to 80/min. The patient is observed in the emergency department over the next 6 hours and her laboratory values and a repeat ECG return within normal limits. The patient suddenly complains of shortness of breath. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. A repeat chest radiograph is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Traumatic (delayed) pneumothorax — most likely a rib‑fracture–related pneumothorax that developed hours after the injury (seen on the repeat chest x‑ray). Sudden dyspnea, tachycardia and hypoxia after blunt chest trauma with a new pleural line/absent peripheral lung markings on CXR are classic; management is tube thoracostomy for symptomatic or large pneumothorax.

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (concealed abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (“board‑like”) uterus, maternal shock and fetal distress in a hypertensive patient are classic for abruption with concealed hemorrhage. Vasa previa typically causes painless vaginal bleeding after membrane rupture and acute fetal exsanguination, and uterine rigidity is not characteristic; uterine rupture is less likely here given a low transverse scar and lack of labor.

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (hypertonic) uterus, maternal shock and fetal bradycardia at 32 weeks all point to a concealed retroplacental hemorrhage. Hypertension is a known risk factor for abruption, and external bleeding can be absent with concealed bleeding. Uterine rupture is less likely here (lower‑segment transverse scar, no loss of station or palpable fetal parts and no active labor described).

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: Sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid/tender (“boardlike”) uterus, maternal hypotension/tachycardia (shock), and fetal bradycardia at 32 weeks are classic for concealed abruption. Maternal HTN is a strong risk factor. Uterine rupture is less likely given no active labor, intact fetal station and minimal cervical dilation.

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (hypertonic) uterus, maternal hypotension/tachycardia and pallor (shock), fetal bradycardia, and a history of hypertension are classic for abruptio placentae — bleeding can be concealed so vaginal blood may be absent. Ruptured vasa previa typically causes painless vaginal bleeding with immediate fetal exsanguination after membrane rupture and lacks uterine tenderness or maternal shock as the primary finding.

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Placental abruption (abruptio placentae) — likely a concealed abruption. 

Rationale: sudden severe pain, a rigid/tender “board‑like” uterus, maternal shock with cool clammy extremities, and fetal distress at 32 weeks are classic for abruption; prior hypertension is a major risk factor. Uterine rupture is less likely (no advanced labor, minimal dilation/unchanged station, no palpable fetal parts).

question:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She does not speak English and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 100.1°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales and dullness to percussion at the lung bases that is worse on the left. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. A thoracentesis and hematologic analysis are performed, with the following results:

Pleural lactate dehydrogenase: 54 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 82 U/L
Proteins, pleural fluid: 3.8 g/dL
Proteins, serum (total): 7.0 g/dL

What conditions is most strongly associated with these findings?
response:
Conclusion: This is an exudative pleural effusion most strongly suggesting malignancy — classically lymphoma in this clinical context.

Reasoning: Light’s criteria are met (pleural/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.54 >0.5; pleural/serum LDH = 54/82 = 0.66 >0.6), so the effusion is exudative. Exudates are caused by infection, malignancy, pulmonary embolism, TB, etc. The concomitant hepatosplenomegaly and systemic signs make a hematologic malignancy (eg, lymphoma with malignant pleural involvement) the most likely association here, rather than an isolated pulmonary embolism.

question:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She does not speak English and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 100.1°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales and dullness to percussion at the lung bases that is worse on the left. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. A thoracentesis and hematologic analysis are performed, with the following results:

Pleural lactate dehydrogenase: 54 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 82 U/L
Proteins, pleural fluid: 3.8 g/dL
Proteins, serum (total): 7.0 g/dL

What conditions is most strongly associated with these findings?
response:
Conclusion: These findings are most consistent with a malignant (hematologic) pleural effusion from lymphoma (or leukemia).

Reasoning: The pleural/serum protein ratio (3.8/7.0 = 0.54) and pleural/serum LDH ratio (54/82 ≈ 0.66) meet Light’s criteria for an exudate. Hepatosplenomegaly and an abnormal hematologic workup point toward a hematologic malignancy (eg, lymphoma or leukemia) causing a malignant exudative effusion. Protein‑losing enteropathy would be expected to cause hypoalbuminemia and transudative effusions, so that is incorrect here.

question:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She does not speak English and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 100.1°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales and dullness to percussion at the lung bases that is worse on the left. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. A thoracentesis and hematologic analysis are performed, with the following results:

Pleural lactate dehydrogenase: 54 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 82 U/L
Proteins, pleural fluid: 3.8 g/dL
Proteins, serum (total): 7.0 g/dL

What conditions is most strongly associated with these findings?
response: No — this is an exudative pleural effusion. Pleural/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.543 (>0.5) and pleural/serum LDH = 54/82 ≈ 0.66 (>0.6), meeting Light’s criteria for an exudate. Exudative effusions are most commonly due to malignancy, infection (parapneumonic/empyema), PE, or TB; the presence of hepatosplenomegaly makes a systemic malignancy such as lymphoma the most likely association.

question:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She does not speak English and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 100.1°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales and dullness to percussion at the lung bases that is worse on the left. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. A thoracentesis and hematologic analysis are performed, with the following results:

Pleural lactate dehydrogenase: 54 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 82 U/L
Proteins, pleural fluid: 3.8 g/dL
Proteins, serum (total): 7.0 g/dL

What conditions is most strongly associated with these findings?
response: Pulmonary embolism. The pleural fluid meets Light’s criteria for an exudate (pleural protein/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.54 >0.5; pleural LDH/serum LDH = 54/82 ≈ 0.66 >0.6). PE commonly produces small, exudative (often bloody) pleural effusions and the presentation of tachycardia, tachypnea, low‑grade fever and basilar radiographic findings (eg, wedge infarct/Hampton’s hump) fits PE. (Hepatosplenomegaly would be atypical for isolated PE and might reflect a separate process.)

question:
A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She does not speak English and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 100.1°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales and dullness to percussion at the lung bases that is worse on the left. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. A thoracentesis and hematologic analysis are performed, with the following results:

Pleural lactate dehydrogenase: 54 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 82 U/L
Proteins, pleural fluid: 3.8 g/dL
Proteins, serum (total): 7.0 g/dL

What conditions is most strongly associated with these findings?
response: These pleural-fluid values meet Light's criteria for an exudative effusion (pleural/serum protein 3.8/7.0 = 0.543 > 0.5; pleural/serum LDH 54/82 ≈ 0.66 > 0.6). Exudates are most strongly associated with infection, malignancy, pulmonary embolism, and inflammatory disease — given the hepatosplenomegaly and systemic findings, a malignant process such as lymphoma is most likely.

question: A 65-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after being knocked over onto the road by a motorcyclist while crossing the street. His past medical history includes an aortic valve replacement 6 years ago, and he has been taking warfarin daily since the procedure. On arrival to the emergency department, the patient is disoriented, cannot correctly name where he is, and complains of nausea and a severe headache. Physical examination is notable for a fixed and dilated pupil in his right eye and the findings seen in Figure A. Neurologic examination also reveals weakness and paralysis in the patient's upper and lower extremities on the left side. What syndromes most likely characterizes this patient’s presentation?
response:
Answer: Uncal (lateral transtentorial) herniation from an acute subdural hematoma.

Reasoning: Elderly, anticoagulated patient with head trauma, worsening headache, vomiting and disorientation plus CT findings (crescent-shaped bleed) fit acute subdural hematoma. Right-sided uncal herniation compresses CN III producing a fixed dilated right pupil and causes contralateral (left) hemiparesis from compression of the cerebral peduncle/hemispheric structures.

question: A 65-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after being knocked over onto the road by a motorcyclist while crossing the street. His past medical history includes an aortic valve replacement 6 years ago, and he has been taking warfarin daily since the procedure. On arrival to the emergency department, the patient is disoriented, cannot correctly name where he is, and complains of nausea and a severe headache. Physical examination is notable for a fixed and dilated pupil in his right eye and the findings seen in Figure A. Neurologic examination also reveals weakness and paralysis in the patient's upper and lower extremities on the left side. What syndromes most likely characterizes this patient’s presentation?
response:
Conclusion: Right-sided acute subdural hematoma producing increased intracranial pressure with transtentorial (uncal) herniation.

Reasoning: His warfarin and blunt head trauma favor tearing of bridging veins (subdural hematoma, classically a crescent-shaped collection on imaging). Mass effect from a right-sided subdural compresses the ipsilateral medial temporal lobe (uncus) against the tentorium, compressing CN III → ipsilateral fixed, dilated pupil, and pressing the crus cerebri → contralateral (left) hemiparesis. Epidural hematoma is less likely in this clinical context (older anticoagulated patient and the typical imaging/mechanism differ).

question: A 65-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after being knocked over onto the road by a motorcyclist while crossing the street. His past medical history includes an aortic valve replacement 6 years ago, and he has been taking warfarin daily since the procedure. On arrival to the emergency department, the patient is disoriented, cannot correctly name where he is, and complains of nausea and a severe headache. Physical examination is notable for a fixed and dilated pupil in his right eye and the findings seen in Figure A. Neurologic examination also reveals weakness and paralysis in the patient's upper and lower extremities on the left side. What syndromes most likely characterizes this patient’s presentation?
response:
Yes — this presentation is most consistent with a right-sided uncal (transtentorial) herniation from an expanding intracranial bleed (likely subdural given trauma on warfarin). 

Reason: a fixed, dilated right pupil reflects compression of the right CN III by the medial temporal lobe (uncus) herniating through the tentorial notch, and the left-sided hemiparesis reflects compression of the descending corticospinal fibers (resulting in contralateral motor deficits). The disorientation, severe headache, nausea/vomiting and the anticoagulation history all support an expanding hemorrhage causing transtentorial herniation.

question: A 65-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after being knocked over onto the road by a motorcyclist while crossing the street. His past medical history includes an aortic valve replacement 6 years ago, and he has been taking warfarin daily since the procedure. On arrival to the emergency department, the patient is disoriented, cannot correctly name where he is, and complains of nausea and a severe headache. Physical examination is notable for a fixed and dilated pupil in his right eye and the findings seen in Figure A. Neurologic examination also reveals weakness and paralysis in the patient's upper and lower extremities on the left side. What syndromes most likely characterizes this patient’s presentation?
response:
Uncal (transtentorial) herniation.

Reason: Trauma on warfarin → intracranial bleed with rising ICP → medial temporal lobe (uncus) forced over the tentorial edge compresses the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (fixed, dilated pupil on the right) and the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle (producing weakness of the contralateral—left—body). Transcalvarial herniation is extrusion through a skull defect and would require a cranial fracture/craniectomy, which the vignette does not describe.

On arrival to the emergency department, the patient is disoriented, cannot correctly name where he is, and complains of nausea and a severe headache. Physical examination is notable for a fixed and dilated pupil in his right eye and the findings seen in Figure A. Neurologic examination also reveals weakness and paralysis in the patient's upper and lower extremities on the left side. What syndromes most likely characterizes this patient’s presentation?
response: An acute subdural hematoma (common in an elderly patient on warfarin) causing transtentorial (uncal) herniation. The herniating medial temporal lobe compresses the ipsilateral CN III → fixed, dilated pupil, and compresses the motor pathways → contralateral hemiparesis.

question:
A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for fatigue. In general, he has been in good health; however, he recently has experienced some weight loss, abdominal pain, and general fatigue. He has a past medical history of anxiety, diabetes, a fracture of his foot sustained when he tripped, and a recent cold that caused him to miss work for a week. His current medications include metformin, insulin, buspirone, vitamin D, calcium, and sodium docusate. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a calm gentleman. A mild systolic murmur is heard in the left upper sternal region. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 12 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Leukocyte count: 66,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 177,000/mm^3
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase: elevated

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.9 mEq/L
AST: 12 U/L
ALT: 10 U/L

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: leukemoid reaction (reactive neutrophilic leukocytosis).

Reasoning: Marked leukocytosis with an elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase points to a reactive process rather than a myeloproliferative neoplasm such as CML (which has low LAP and basophilia). Acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma would show blasts and is more common in children/young adults; here the differential is described as normal with no blasts and the clinical picture (mild fever, weight loss/abdominal pain) fits a reactive/paraneoplastic leukemoid response.

There’s no mention of basophilia or classic splenomegaly that you’d expect with CML. Next steps would be to examine a peripheral smear for toxic granulation/Döhle bodies, search for an infectious/ inflammatory or occult malignant source, and only pursue BCR‑ABL testing if features suggest CML despite the high LAP.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: leukemoid reaction.

ALL would usually show circulating lymphoblasts on the differential, thrombocytopenia and marrow lymphoblast proliferation (and is much more common in children). An elevated LAP distinguishes a leukemoid reaction from CML (which typically has low LAP).

What is the most likely diagnosis?

The WBC is markedly elevated but the leukocyte alkaline phosphatase is high (in leukemoid reactions LAP is elevated; in CML LAP is low), there's no basophilia, and platelets are not markedly increased — all favor a reactive process (eg postinfectious or paraneoplastic) over chronic myelogenous leukemia.

question: A 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the clinic by his mother because of pruritic vesicles that appeared on the left side of his torso 12 hours ago. One day earlier, before the appearance of the vesicles, the patient’s mother notes that he had been complaining of a burning sensation in that area. The boy has been receiving chemotherapy consisting of methotrexate, cytarabine, and cyclophosphamide for 1 month. He received the last treatment 2 days ago. He has no other past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Upon physical examination, there are painful vesicles are localized to the left C7 skin dermatome (see image). What is the most likely etiology of the skin lesions in this patient?
truth: Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy
response:
Conclusion: These lesions are herpes zoster (shingles) — reactivation of latent varicella‑zoster virus in a dorsal root (cervical) ganglion due to chemotherapy‑induced immunosuppression.

Reasoning: The unilateral, painful, vesicular rash confined to a single dermatome with a prodrome of burning is classic for VZV reactivation. Primary varicella (chickenpox) is a diffuse, generalized vesicular rash, not a unilateral dermatomal eruption.

question: A 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the clinic by his mother because of pruritic vesicles that appeared on the left side of his torso 12 hours ago. One day earlier, before the appearance of the vesicles, the patient’s mother notes that he had been complaining of a burning sensation in that area. The boy has been receiving chemotherapy consisting of methotrexate, cytarabine, and cyclophosphamide for 1 month. He received the last treatment 2 days ago. He has no other past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Upon physical examination, there are painful vesicles are localized to the left C7 skin dermatome (see image). What is the most likely etiology of the skin lesions in this patient?
truth: Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy
response:
The most likely etiology is reactivation of latent varicella‑zoster virus (herpes zoster) in a dorsal root ganglion triggered by chemotherapy‑induced immunosuppression.

Reasoning: a unilateral, painful vesicular eruption strictly in a single dermatome with a prodrome of burning/neuropathic pain is classic for zoster. Primary varicella would be diffuse, generalized vesicles with systemic symptoms; other causes (contact dermatitis, HSV) do not produce a unilateral dermatomal pattern in the trunk. The child’s recent chemotherapy lowers cellular immunity, increasing risk of VZV reactivation.

question: A 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the clinic by his mother because of pruritic vesicles that appeared on the left side of his torso 12 hours ago. One day earlier, before the appearance of the vesicles, the patient’s mother notes that he had been complaining of a burning sensation in that area. The boy has been receiving chemotherapy consisting of methotrexate, cytarabine, and cyclophosphamide for 1 month. He received the last treatment 2 days ago. He has no other past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Upon physical examination, there are painful vesicles are localized to the left C7 skin dermatome (see image). What is the most likely etiology of the skin lesions in this patient?
truth: Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy
response:
Conclusion: This is herpes zoster — reactivation of latent varicella‑zoster virus (an enveloped dsDNA alpha‑herpesvirus) in a dorsal root ganglion precipitated by chemotherapy‑induced immunosuppression.

Reasoning: The brief burning prodrome followed by painful, grouped vesicles confined to a single unilateral dermatome is classic for VZV reactivation (shingles). Chemotherapy (reduced cell‑mediated immunity) increases the risk of reactivation. HSV is less likely given the dermatomal distribution and single‑dermatome presentation.

question: A 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the clinic by his mother because of pruritic vesicles that appeared on the left side of his torso 12 hours ago. One day earlier, before the appearance of the vesicles, the patient’s mother notes that he had been complaining of a burning sensation in that area. The boy has been receiving chemotherapy consisting of methotrexate, cytarabine, and cyclophosphamide for 1 month. He received the last treatment 2 days ago. He has no other past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Upon physical examination, there are painful vesicles are localized to the left C7 skin dermatome (see image). What is the most likely etiology of the skin lesions in this patient?
truth: Reactivation of VZV due to immunodeficiency caused by chemotherapy
response:
No — this is most likely reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (herpes zoster, “shingles”) due to chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression.  

Reason: the rash is unilateral and confined to a single dermatome (left C7) with a burning, painful prodrome — classic for zoster. Primary varicella (chickenpox) produces a diffuse, generalized vesicular rash (lesions in multiple stages) and systemic symptoms, not a single-dermatome distribution.

question: A 9-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the clinic by his mother because of pruritic vesicles that appeared on the left side of his torso 12 hours ago.
