question: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated density at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this density is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
response:
Conclusion: Small cell (oat cell) carcinoma of the lung.

Reasoning: A heavy smoker with a central/hilar mass and severe hyponatremia causing seizures is most consistent with ectopic ADH secretion (SIADH) from small cell lung cancer. Microscopically you would see sheets of small cells with scant cytoplasm, finely granular ("salt-and-pepper") chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, high mitotic rate and necrosis (neuroendocrine phenotype).

question: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated density at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this density is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
response:
Conclusion: Small cell (oat cell) carcinoma of the lung.

Reasoning: A heavy smoker with a central/hilar irregular mass, 6 months of cough/weight loss, acute confusion and a tonic–clonic seizure, and marked hyponatremia (Na+ 119 mEq/L) is most consistent with ectopic ADH production (SIADH) from small cell carcinoma. Microscopically you would see small, round/blue cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear molding, high mitotic rate and necrosis (neuroendocrine features; chromogranin/synaptophysin positive). Other lung cancers (adenocarcinoma—peripheral; squamous—paraneoplastic hypercalcemia) are less consistent with this presentation.

question: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated density at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this density is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
response:
Answer: Small cell (oat cell) carcinoma of the lung.

Reason: A heavy smoker with a central/hilar mass, chronic cough, profound hyponatremia (Na 119) presenting with seizure fits SIADH from small cell carcinoma. On microscopy you would see small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill‑defined cell borders, nuclear molding, finely granular ("salt‑and‑pepper") chromatin, high mitotic rate and necrosis; tumor cells are neuroendocrine (chromogranin/synaptophysin positive).

question: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated density at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this density is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
response:
No — small cell (oat cell) carcinoma is most likely.  

Reason: the profound hyponatremia (Na+ 119) with seizure in a smoker with a central/hilar lung mass is classic for ectopic ADH secretion (SIADH), which is most commonly caused by small cell lung carcinoma. Squamous cell is also a central tumor in smokers but is classically associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia (PTHrP) and different histology (keratin pearls/intercellular bridges).

question: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated density at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this density is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
response: Small (oat cell) carcinoma of the lung — sheets of small, round blue cells with scant cytoplasm, finely granular (“salt‑and‑pepper”) chromatin, nuclear molding and high mitotic rate (neuroendocrine/Kulchitsky cell features). This tumor often secretes ADH (SIADH) causing hyponatremia and seizures.

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted. What best describes the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Conclusion: This is most consistent with a secondary spontaneous pneumothorax from rupture of an apical emphysematous (subpleural) bleb.

Reasoning: Sudden severe dyspnea in an older heavy smoker, markedly low O2 despite supplemental oxygen and unilateral diminished breath sounds over the right upper zone are classic for pneumothorax from ruptured emphysematous bleb (secondary spontaneous pneumothorax). The absence of classic tension signs (severe hypotension, tracheal deviation, JVD) makes simple/large pneumothorax more likely than tension physiology.

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted. What best describes the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: right-sided secondary spontaneous pneumothorax from rupture of an apical bleb (acute lung collapse).

Reasoning: sudden onset dyspnea in a heavy long‑time smoker with probable underlying emphysema/COPD, focal absence of breath sounds over the right upper lobe, severe hypoxemia not improving with supplemental O2, and tachycardia/ tachypnea all fit a large spontaneous pneumothorax. This is distinct from cardiogenic pulmonary edema (would give bilateral crackles, diffuse rales, and signs of low cardiac output) and from methemoglobinemia (would not produce unilateral absent breath sounds or a focal lung exam). Immediate management is urgent decompression (needle if tension physiology, then chest tube).

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted. What best describes the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely a secondary spontaneous pneumothorax (right apical) from rupture of an apical bleb causing acute lung collapse and severe V/Q mismatch.

Reasoning: sudden-onset dyspnea in a long-time smoker, unilateral diminished breath sounds over the right upper lobe, tachycardia/tachypnea, and severe hypoxemia that is poorly responsive to supplemental O2 are classic for pneumothorax from ruptured blebs in patients with underlying smoking-related lung disease.

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted. What best describes the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Conclusion: Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax from rupture of an emphysematous (apical) bleb.

Reasoning: Sudden severe dyspnea in a long-time smoker with diminished breath sounds localized to the right upper lobe and profound hypoxemia despite supplemental O2 is classic for pneumothorax from a ruptured bleb in emphysema. The acute unilateral physical findings (rather than bilateral crackles/foamy sputum of pulmonary edema) and smoking/COPD risk point to secondary spontaneous pneumothorax; urgent decompression/chest tube is indicated for a large or clinically significant pneumothorax.

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted. What best describes the most likely diagnosis?
response: Most likely methemoglobinemia: oxidizing exposure converted heme iron from Fe2+ to Fe3+ (methemoglobin), which cannot bind O2 → functional anemia with tissue hypoxia, low pulse oximetry that does not correct with supplemental O2 despite a normal PaO2, “chocolate‑brown” blood; treatment is IV methylene blue (or exchange transfusion if severe).

question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by his babysitter when she found him in this manner. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states he is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: caustic (corrosive) ingestion causing acute oral burns.

Reasoning: sudden onset while unsupervised, severe odynophagia with heavy drooling and an erythematous, swollen tongue are classic for an acute caustic injury to the mouth/throat. The picture is less typical for epiglottitis (would usually have higher fever, muffled voice/stridor) or allergic angioedema (usually painless swelling, urticaria, or airway compromise). Management is emergent airway assessment, avoid inducing vomiting or neutralization, and urgent ENT/gastroenterology evaluation (endoscopy) for injury assessment.

question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by his babysitter when she found him in this manner. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states he is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Ludwig’s angina (bilateral submandibular-space cellulitis).

Reasoning: Acute painful drooling and inability to swallow with an acutely enlarged, erythematous, elevated tongue is classic for a rapidly spreading submandibular/floor-of-mouth infection that pushes the tongue upward. Insecticide/organophosphate exposure would produce diffuse cholinergic signs (miosis, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, diaphoresis), not an isolated painful, erythematous tongue. Immediate management focuses on airway protection and IV broad‑spectrum antibiotics with surgical consultation for drainage if needed.

question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by his babysitter when she found him in this manner. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states he is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: acute angioedema (allergic reaction) causing tongue swelling.

Reasoning: sudden drooling, odynophagia and inability to swallow with an acutely enlarged, erythematous tongue points to rapid soft‑tissue swelling of the oropharynx. Lack of high fever, trismus, uvular deviation, or focal dental/submandibular findings makes epiglottitis, peritonsillar abscess, and Ludwig’s angina less likely. Organophosphate/insecticide toxicity would produce cholinergic signs (miosis, bronchorrhea, bradycardia), which are absent.

question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by his babysitter when she found him in this manner. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states he is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: caustic ingestion (oral chemical burn).

Reasoning: acute onset drooling, severe odynophagia, and an erythematous, swollen tongue after being unsupervised are classic for a caustic burn to the oropharynx. The picture lacks the cholinergic signs of organophosphate poisoning and lacks the fever/stridor pattern of classic epiglottitis or the urticaria/hypotension typical of anaphylactic angioedema. Immediate priorities are airway protection and urgent ENT/gastroenterology evaluation (endoscopy) — do not induce emesis or attempt neutralization.

question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by his babysitter when she found him in this manner. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states he is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Ludwig angina — rapidly progressive submandibular/sublingual cellulitis (usually odontogenic) causing floor-of-mouth swelling, elevation/enlargement of the tongue, drooling, dysphagia and risk of airway compromise.

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. Review of symptoms is significant for a mild, low-grade fever, fatigue, and nausea for the past week. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection for which she is not currently receiving therapy. Her CD4+ T cell count last month was 250/mm3. The blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, the pulse rate is 90/min, and the temperature is 37.7°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is conscious but drowsy. Papilledema is present. No pain is elicited with extension of the leg at the knee joint. The remainder of the physical examination is negative. Laboratory findings, including panculture, are ordered. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is negative and is followed by a lumbar puncture. CSF analysis is significant for:
Opening pressure 250 mm H2O (70-180 mm H2O)
Glucose 30 mg/dL (40-70 mg/dL)
Protein 100 mg/dL (<40 mg/dL)
Cell count 20/mm3 (0-5/mm3)
What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
truth: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
response:
Conclusion: You would most likely find encapsulated budding yeast (Cryptococcus neoformans) on India ink or a positive cryptococcal antigen test in the CSF — not Gram‑positive diplococci.

Reasoning: The subacute course in an HIV patient, very high opening pressure, low CSF glucose, mildly elevated protein and low‑to‑moderate lymphocytic pleocytosis, and papilledema are classic for cryptococcal meningitis. Cryptococcus is an encapsulated yeast seen with India ink/mucicarmine staining or by cryptococcal capsular antigen detection (latex agglutination), rather than Gram‑positive diplococci.

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. Review of symptoms is significant for a mild, low-grade fever, fatigue, and nausea for the past week. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection for which she is not currently receiving therapy. Her CD4+ T cell count last month was 250/mm3. The blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, the pulse rate is 90/min, and the temperature is 37.7°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is conscious but drowsy. Papilledema is present. No pain is elicited with extension of the leg at the knee joint. The remainder of the physical examination is negative. Laboratory findings, including panculture, are ordered. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is negative and is followed by a lumbar puncture. CSF analysis is significant for:
Opening pressure 250 mm H2O (70-180 mm H2O)
Glucose 30 mg/dL (40-70 mg/dL)
Protein 100 mg/dL (<40 mg/dL)
Cell count 20/mm3 (0-5/mm3)
What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
truth: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
response:
Conclusion: The most likely additional finding is a positive cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen (CrAg) in the CSF (and/or growth of mucoid, encapsulated yeast on fungal culture / mucicarmine-positive capsule).

Reasoning: Subacute headache in an HIV patient with elevated opening pressure, papilledema, low CSF glucose, elevated protein and lymphocytic pleocytosis is classic for cryptococcal meningitis. India ink can show encapsulated yeast but is relatively insensitive; the CrAg test is more sensitive and is the preferred diagnostic finding.

A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. Review of symptoms is significant for a mild, low-grade fever, fatigue, and nausea for the past week. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection for which she is not currently receiving therapy. Her CD4+ T cell count last month was 250/mm3. The blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, the pulse rate is 90/min, and the temperature is 37.7°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is conscious but drowsy. Papilledema is present. No pain is elicited with extension of the leg at the knee joint. The remainder of the physical examination is negative. Laboratory findings, including panculture, are ordered. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is negative and is followed by a lumbar puncture. CSF analysis is significant for:
Opening pressure 250 mm H2O (70-180 mm H2O)
Glucose 30 mg/dL (40-70 mg/dL)
Protein 100 mg/dL (<40 mg/dL)
Cell count 20/mm3 (0-5/mm3)
What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
truth: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
response:
Positive cryptococcal test — e.g., CSF India ink showing encapsulated budding yeast and/or positive cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen (Cryptococcus neoformans).

Reason: Subacute headache, raised intracranial pressure with papilledema, mild fever, minimal meningeal signs, elevated opening pressure, low CSF glucose, elevated protein with only a modest pleocytosis in an HIV patient are classic for cryptococcal meningitis. (Although cryptococcus is most common with CD4 <100, it can occur at higher counts.)

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
truth: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
response:
No — the most likely finding is encapsulated yeast cells (Cryptococcus neoformans) on India ink (or positive cryptococcal antigen).

Reasoning: subacute course in an HIV patient with increased intracranial pressure (papilledema, high opening pressure), low CSF glucose, elevated protein and only mild pleocytosis (20 cells) is typical of cryptococcal meningitis. Bacterial (pneumococcal) meningitis presents acutely with high fever, neutrophil‑predominant CSF and very high WBC counts — not the pattern seen here.

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. Review of symptoms is significant for a mild, low-grade fever, fatigue, and nausea for the past week. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection for which she is not currently receiving therapy. Her CD4+ T cell count last month was 250/mm3. The blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, the pulse rate is 90/min, and the temperature is 37.7°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is conscious but drowsy. Papilledema is present. No pain is elicited with extension of the leg at the knee joint. The remainder of the physical examination is negative. Laboratory findings, including panculture, are ordered. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is negative and is followed by a lumbar puncture. CSF analysis is significant for:
Opening pressure 250 mm H2O (70-180 mm H2O)
Glucose 30 mg/dL (40-70 mg/dL)
Protein 100 mg/dL (<40 mg/dL)
Cell count 20/mm3 (0-5/mm3)
What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
truth: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
response: Findings consistent with Cryptococcus neoformans infection — e.g., encapsulated, budding yeast on India ink (or positive cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen in CSF/serum; urease-positive growth on Sabouraud agar).

question: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) — infection by Malassezia species (formerly Malassezia furfur).

Reasoning: young adult with recurrent summer-predominant, mildly pruritic, uneven/hypopigmented macules on the chest and arms fits pityriasis versicolor; it is exacerbated by heat/humidity and often noticed because lesions contrast with suntanned skin. Diagnosis is confirmed by KOH prep showing short hyphae and round spores ("spaghetti and meatballs"); treatment is topical selenium sulfide or azole therapy.

question: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: tinea (pityriasis) versicolor due to Malassezia species.

Reasoning: recurrent summer flares of “uneven” hypopigmented macules on the chest and upper extremities that can be mildly pruritic and become more obvious after tanning are classic for pityriasis versicolor. Lesions typically show fine scaling, KOH prep reveals “spaghetti-and-meatballs” yeast and hyphae, and fluoresce yellow‑green on Wood’s lamp. Halo nevi are depigmented rings around individual nevi and do not present as widespread seasonal macules. Treatment is with topical selenium sulfide or azoles (or oral azoles for extensive disease).

question: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: tinea (pityriasis) versicolor due to Malassezia.

Reasoning: recurrent summer-only rash on the chest and upper arms with uneven, sometimes itchy, fine-scaled macules that can look like “peeling” or hypopigmented/hyperpigmented spots is classic for pityriasis versicolor. KOH prep shows “spaghetti-and-meatballs” yeast and hyphae; treat with topical selenium sulfide, ketoconazole, or azoles (or oral fluconazole/itraconazole for extensive disease).

question: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) due to Malassezia species.

Reasoning: Scaly, patchy hypopigmented/hyperpigmented macules on the chest and upper arms that become more apparent in summer (lesions fail to tan) and are sometimes mildly pruritic are classic for Malassezia (KOH: “spaghetti and meatballs”). This fits far better than halo nevi (isolated depigmented rings around individual nevi) or vitiligo. Treatment is topical ketoconazole or selenium sulfide (oral azoles for extensive disease).

question: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) due to Malassezia species — recurrent hypopigmented, scaly macules on the trunk/upper arms that become obvious in summer.

question:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.31
PCO2 55 mm Hg
PO2 42 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 76%
The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic rupture of a major airway (tracheobronchial injury) with pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema.

Reasoning: blunt chest trauma with palpable crepitus (subcutaneous emphysema) and a precordial crunch synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign) indicate air in the mediastinum. Decreased breath sounds on the right after high‑speed MVC point to a right-sided airway injury allowing air leak (and possibly associated hemothorax), accounting for severe hypoxemia.

question:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.31
PCO2 55 mm Hg
PO2 42 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 76%
The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic tracheobronchial (mainstem bronchus) rupture with pneumomediastinum and associated hemothorax.

Reasoning: high‑speed blunt chest trauma + crepitus of the chest (subcutaneous emphysema) and a crunch synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign = pneumomediastinum) are classic for airway rupture. Decreased breath sounds and dullness on the right reflect blood/pleural fluid from associated lung/pleural injury. The severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia despite respiratory effort also fit a major airway disruption. (Findings such as flail chest or isolated pneumothorax would give different exam/percussion findings — eg, paradoxical chest wall motion or hyperresonance rather than a mediastinal crunch.)

question:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.31
PCO2 55 mm Hg
PO2 42 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 76%
The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic rupture of the right mainstem bronchus (tracheobronchial injury).

Reasoning: blunt chest trauma with subcutaneous crepitation and a precordial “crunch” (Hamman’s sign) indicates pneumomediastinum/subcutaneous emphysema from an air leak. The focal loss of breath sounds on the right, severe hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis are classic for a major bronchial injury (right main bronchus is most commonly involved). Findings don’t fit isolated simple pneumothorax (would be hyperresonant) or cardiac rupture (would cause shock and tamponade).

The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

PCO2 55 mm Hg
PO2 42 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 76%
The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
response:
Most likely a traumatic tracheobronchial rupture with pneumomediastinum (bronchial injury).

Reasoning: the precordial “crunch” synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign) plus palpable crepitus = pneumomediastinum/subcutaneous emphysema seen with tracheobronchial disruption. Decreased breath sounds on the right with severe hypoxemia fit major airway injury. Findings argue against tension pneumothorax, which usually produces hyperresonance, hypotension and JVD/tracheal deviation — features absent here (percussion is dull, BP is preserved).

question: A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a change in his mental status. The patient’s daughter states that he can cook and clean up after himself and only needs help paying bills. Yesterday the patient seemed fine; however, this morning she noticed that he struggled to perform simple tasks and was forgetful while cooking, leaving the stove on. They recently returned from a trip to Mexico and admit to drinking unfiltered water and eating local cuisines while abroad. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 187/118 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: delirium (acute confusional state).

Reasoning: the cognitive change is acute (overnight), fluctuating and a clear change from his prior baseline of independent function — classic for delirium. Vascular dementia is a chronic, often stepwise decline over months/years after strokes, not a sudden one‑day change. In an elderly patient recent travel, infection, metabolic disturbance, medications, or hypertensive emergency are common precipitants and should be evaluated promptly.

His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 187/118 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: delirium (acute confusional state), not Alzheimer disease.

Reasoning: the mental change was abrupt (overnight), with fluctuating attention/ability to perform tasks in a previously independent patient — classic for delirium. Alzheimer dementia is insidious, progressive over months–years with gradual memory decline, not an acute overnight change. Recent travel/unfiltered water, marked hypertension, infection, metabolic disturbance, or medications are plausible reversible precipitants of delirium and should be investigated.

response:

Reasoning: the mental-status change is acute (overnight) with new impairment in attention and ability to perform tasks in a patient who was previously independent — this pattern fits delirium, not Alzheimer disease which is insidious, progressive, and months–years in onset. The recent travel, possible infection/dehydration, medications, or metabolic/vascular stress (notably severe hypertension) are plausible precipitants.

question: A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a change in his mental status. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 187/118 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Delirium (acute confusional state). 

Rationale: sudden, acute change in attention and ability to perform tasks in a patient with previously intact cognition—consistent with delirium rather than chronic dementia; recent travel/illness, metabolic or infectious precipitants are likely contributors.

question:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of difficulty walking for the past 4 hours. She first noticed her symptoms after getting up this morning and her foot dragging while walking. She feels tired. She has a history of chronic sinusitis. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroids. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 80/min, and her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Auscultation of her lungs shows diffuse wheezing over bilateral lung fields. Physical examination shows tender subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows. There are palpable, non-blanching erythematous lesions on both shins. Dorsiflexion of the right foot is impaired. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the ulnar aspect of the left forearm. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 24,500
Segmented neutrophils 48%
Eosinophils 29%
Lymphocytes 19%
Monocytes 4%
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen 32 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.85 mg/dL
Urine
Blood 2+
Protein 3+
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?"
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg–Strauss).

Reasoning: Adult with new/worsening asthma and chronic sinusitis plus marked peripheral eosinophilia (absolute eosinophils ��7,100), systemic vasculitic features—mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop, ulnar sensory loss), skin nodules/palpable purpura, and renal involvement (hematuria/proteinuria, ↑Cr). These findings are classic for EGPA (often p‑ANCA/MPO positive) and distinguish it from granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which does not feature prominent asthma/eosinophilia.

Most likely diagnosis: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg–Strauss).

Reasoning: Classic triad here — adult-onset asthma and chronic sinusitis, marked peripheral eosinophilia (~7,000/µL), and systemic small‑vessel vasculitis with mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop), palpable purpura/skin nodules, fever and renal involvement (hematuria/proteinuria, elevated BUN/Cr). GPA (Wegener) or microscopic polyangiitis are less likely because they do not feature the prominent eosinophilia and antecedent asthma/allergic history seen in EGPA.

response:
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly Churg–Strauss).

Reasoning: adult with new systemic vasculitic signs plus a history of asthma and chronic sinusitis, marked peripheral eosinophilia (~29%, absolute >1.5K), fever, migratory/wheezing pulmonary disease, mononeuritis multiplex causing foot drop and sensory loss, palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules, and renal involvement (hematuria/proteinuria, ↑BUN/Cr). These features meet diagnostic criteria for EGPA and fit far better than alternatives (eg, GPA/Wegener would not have prominent asthma/eosinophilia; PAN lacks pulmonary/airway asthma and marked eosinophilia).

question:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with ongoing dyspnea and confusion for 2 hours. She has a history of psychosis and alcohol abuse. She has smoked 1 pack per day for 25 years. She is agitated and confused. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg; pulse 110/min; respirations 35/min; and temperature, 36.7°C (98.1°F). The pulmonary examination shows tachypnea and mild generalized wheezing. Auscultation of the heart shows no abnormal sounds. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
CI- 100 mEq/L
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air
pH 7.37
pCO2 21 mm Hg
pO2 88 mm Hg
HCO3- 12 mEq/L
What best explains these findings?
response:
Conclusion: This is a mixed high–anion-gap metabolic acidosis plus respiratory alkalosis most consistent with acute salicylate (aspirin) poisoning — not simple alcoholic ketoacidosis.

Reasoning: HCO3− is low (12 mEq/L) indicating metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap = 138 − (100 + 12) = 26. Expected respiratory compensation (Winter’s) pCO2 ≈ 1.5×12 + 8 ≈ 26 mm Hg, but the measured pCO2 is 21 mm Hg → an additional primary respiratory alkalosis. The combination of low HCO3−, low pCO2, near‑normal pH, tachypnea, confusion and an at‑risk patient is classic for salicylate toxicity (early central hyperventilation with metabolic acidosis).

question:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with ongoing dyspnea and confusion for 2 hours. She has a history of psychosis and alcohol abuse. She has smoked 1 pack per day for 25 years. She is agitated and confused. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg; pulse 110/min; respirations 35/min; and temperature, 36.7°C (98.1°F). The pulmonary examination shows tachypnea and mild generalized wheezing. Auscultation of the heart shows no abnormal sounds. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
CI- 100 mEq/L
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air
pH 7.37
pCO2 21 mm Hg
pO2 88 mm Hg
HCO3- 12 mEq/L
What best explains these findings?
response:
Conclusion: These results show a mixed respiratory alkalosis and high–anion-gap metabolic acidosis most consistent with acute salicylate (aspirin) intoxication.

Reasoning: pCO2 is markedly low (21 mm Hg) and HCO3– is low (12 mEq/L) with a near‑normal pH (7.37) — the pattern of simultaneous primary respiratory alkalosis plus metabolic acidosis. Calculated anion gap = 138 − (100 + 12) = 26 (elevated), consistent with an anion‑gap metabolic acidosis. Salicylates classically stimulate ventilation (early respiratory alkalosis) and produce an anion‑gap metabolic acidosis from accumulation of organic acids and impaired oxidative metabolism, so this mixed ABG picture is typical; confirm by measuring serum salicylate level.

question:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with ongoing dyspnea and confusion for 2 hours. She has a history of psychosis and alcohol abuse. She has smoked 1 pack per day for 25 years. She is agitated and confused. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg; pulse 110/min; respirations 35/min; and temperature, 36.7°C (98.1°F). The pulmonary examination shows tachypnea and mild generalized wheezing. Auscultation of the heart shows no abnormal sounds. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air

pO2 88 mm Hg
HCO3- 12 mEq/L
What best explains these findings?
response:
Conclusion: Mixed primary respiratory alkalosis plus high-anion-gap metabolic acidosis — most consistent with acute salicylate (aspirin) intoxication.

Reasoning: pH is near normal with both low pCO2 (21 mm Hg) and low HCO3− (12 mEq/L), indicating a mixed disorder. Anion gap = 138 − (100 + 12) = 26 (elevated). Expected pCO2 for simple metabolic acidosis (HCO3− 12) ≈ 1.5×12 + 8 = 26 mm Hg, but observed pCO2 is 21 mm Hg → additional primary respiratory alkalosis. Salicylates classically cause primary respiratory alkalosis (central hyperventilation) plus an anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and the clinical picture (agitation, confusion, hyperventilation) fits.

A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with ongoing dyspnea and confusion for 2 hours. She has a history of psychosis and alcohol abuse. She has smoked 1 pack per day for 25 years. She is agitated and confused. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg; pulse 110/min; respirations 35/min; and temperature, 36.7°C (98.1°F). pCO2 21 mm Hg
pO2 88 mm Hg
HCO3- 12 mEq/L
What best explains these findings?
response:
Salicylate (aspirin) intoxication.

Reasoning: The patient has a high–anion-gap metabolic acidosis (AG = 138 − [100+12] = 26) with HCO3− = 12, but the pH is near normal because there is a concurrent respiratory alkalosis: expected pCO2 for simple metabolic acidosis (Winter’s formula) ≈ 1.5×12+8 ≈ 26 mm Hg, yet measured pCO2 is 21 mm Hg (excessive hyperventilation). A mixed metabolic acidosis + primary respiratory alkalosis is classic for acute salicylate poisoning; alcoholic ketoacidosis would produce a primary metabolic acidosis with an appropriate respiratory compensation (pCO2 nearer to the expected value).

The classic cause producing both early respiratory alkalosis and anion‑gap metabolic acidosis is acute salicylate (aspirin) intoxication — the best explanation given her presentation and risk factors.

question:
A 60-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department with an altered mental status. He is not answering questions. His past medical history is unknown. A venous blood gas is drawn demonstrating the following.

Venous blood gas
pH: 7.2
PaO2: 80 mmHg
PaCO2: 80 mmHg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
response: Correct — acute heroin (opioid) overdose causing respiratory depression. The high PaCO2 with low pH and a near-normal HCO3- indicates an acute respiratory acidosis from hypoventilation (no renal compensation yet), which is classic for opioid-induced respiratory depression.

question:
A 60-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department with an altered mental status. He is not answering questions. His past medical history is unknown. A venous blood gas is drawn demonstrating the following.

Venous blood gas
pH: 7.2
PaO2: 80 mmHg
PaCO2: 80 mmHg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
response:
Most likely acute respiratory acidosis from hypoventilation — e.g., opioid/sedative overdose causing CO2 retention.

Reasoning: pH 7.2 with PaCO2 of 80 mmHg and a near‑normal HCO3− (24 mEq/L) indicates a primary respiratory acidosis without metabolic compensation (acute CO2 retention). Diabetic ketoacidosis would produce a metabolic acidosis (low HCO3−) with respiratory alkalosis compensation (low PaCO2), so DKA does not fit these values.

question:

Venous blood gas

PaCO2: 80 mmHg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
response:
Acute respiratory acidosis from hypoventilation — most likely opioid/sedative overdose causing respiratory depression.

Reason: pH 7.2 with a markedly elevated CO2 (80 mmHg) and near‑normal HCO3– indicates a primary acute respiratory acidosis (acute CO2 retention without metabolic compensation), which fits acute hypoventilation in an obtunded patient.

question:
A 60-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department with an altered mental status. He is not answering questions. His past medical history is unknown. A venous blood gas is drawn demonstrating the following.

Venous blood gas
pH: 7.2
PaO2: 80 mmHg
PaCO2: 80 mmHg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
response:
Heroin (opioid) overdose — acute respiratory acidosis from hypoventilation.

Reason: pH 7.2 with an elevated PaCO2 of 80 mmHg and a normal HCO3− (24) indicates an acute, uncompensated respiratory acidosis (CO2 retention). Opioids (eg, heroin) depress central respiratory drive causing hypoventilation and CO2 retention. This pattern is not consistent with DKA, which would show metabolic acidosis (low HCO3−) with respiratory compensation (low CO2).

question:
A 60-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department with an altered mental status. He is not answering questions. His past medical history is unknown. A venous blood gas is drawn demonstrating the following.

Venous blood gas
pH: 7.2
PaO2: 80 mmHg
PaCO2: 80 mmHg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
response:
This is acute respiratory acidosis from acute hypoventilation — most likely opioid (or other CNS depressant) overdose causing respiratory depression. 

Rationale: marked ↑PaCO2 (80 mmHg) with acidemia (pH 7.2) and normal HCO3− indicates a primary respiratory problem without metabolic/renal compensation (acute process).

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. She appears well. Her temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. Her cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: vasovagal (neurocardiogenic) syncope with brief convulsive movements.

Reasoning: The event was precipitated by pain/emotion (tattoo), had prodromal diaphoresis/pallor, brief loss of consciousness with rapid recovery (<30s) and no postictal confusion or focal deficits. Brief myoclonic jerks can occur with syncope; features argue against a primary generalized tonic–clonic seizure (longer LOC, postictal state, tongue biting/incontinence more common).

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. She appears well. Her temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. Her cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: vasovagal (neurally mediated) syncope.

Reasoning: The event was precipitated by a painful/emotional stimulus (tattooing), with prodromal diaphoresis and pallor, brief loss of consciousness with only a few seconds of jerking, and immediate recovery without a postictal state or focal deficits — all typical of vasovagal syncope. Brief myoclonic-type movements commonly occur with cerebral hypoperfusion and do not indicate epilepsy. The incomplete RBBB on ECG is an incidental finding and does not explain an otherwise classic vasovagal picture.

Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Yes — vasovagal (neurocardiogenic) syncope. 

Reason: She had a typical prodrome (pallor, diaphoresis) with a clear trigger (pain/emotional stress during tattooing), brief LOC with short involuntary jerks, immediate recovery without postictal confusion or focal deficits, and otherwise normal exam/ECG. Those features favor vasovagal syncope over seizure or cardiac arrhythmia.

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. She appears well. Her temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. Her cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: vasovagal (neurocardiogenic) syncope.

Reasoning: she had a clear situational trigger (pain/emotional stress during tattooing) with prodrome (pallor, diaphoresis), a brief loss of consciousness with rapid recovery within 30 seconds and immediate full orientation, and only brief limb jerking (convulsive syncope/myoclonic activity can occur). In contrast, generalized tonic–clonic seizures usually have a longer tonic/clonic phase, a prolonged postictal period with confusion, and more commonly tongue biting or incontinence. Normal neurologic exam and the benign ECG (incomplete RBBB) further support vasovagal syncope. If uncertainty remains, consider EEG and cardiology evaluation (tilt-table, ambulatory monitoring).

response: Neurally mediated (vasovagal) syncope — classic prodrome with pallor/diaphoresis after a painful/emotional trigger, brief LOC with transient myoclonic jerks from cerebral hypoperfusion and immediate, full recovery (no postictal state).

question: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend 10 minutes after ingesting at least 15 acetaminophen tablets. She has been admitted to the hospital several times in the past few months after attempted self-harm. She claims that her boyfriend is “extremely selfish” and “does not care for her.” She says she feels lonely and wants her boyfriend to pay attention to her. Her boyfriend says that they have broken up 10 times in the past year because she is prone to outbursts of physical aggression as well as mood swings. He says that these mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of “exuberance and affection” to states of “depression.” On examination, the patient appears well-dressed and calm. She has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Borderline personality disorder.

Reasoning: Recurrent impulsive self-harm, unstable/ stormy interpersonal relationships, intense short-lived mood swings (hours), anger and attention-seeking behavior fit BPD. Cyclothymic or bipolar disorders cause more sustained mood episodes (days–weeks), and cyclothymia requires chronic subthreshold mood symptoms over years rather than the rapid, interpersonal- and impulsivity-driven pattern seen here.

question: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend 10 minutes after ingesting at least 15 acetaminophen tablets. Her boyfriend says that they have broken up 10 times in the past year because she is prone to outbursts of physical aggression as well as mood swings. He says that these mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of “exuberance and affection” to states of “depression.” On examination, the patient appears well-dressed and calm. She has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Borderline personality disorder.

Reasoning: She has recurrent self-harm/overdose, impulsivity and aggression, unstable/stormy interpersonal relationships with fears of abandonment (blaming boyfriend, wanting attention), and affective instability with mood shifts that last hours — all core features of BPD. Histrionic disorder may involve attention-seeking and shallow emotions but does not typically produce recurrent suicidal behavior, severe identity/interpersonal instability, or the intense affective lability seen here. Bipolar disorder is less likely because mood episodes in bipolar disorder last days to weeks and are pervasive, not brief hours-long shifts.

response:
Most likely diagnosis: borderline personality disorder.

Bipolar disorder is less likely because mood episodes in bipolar last days–weeks (not brief, reactive hours) and histrionic personality disorder emphasizes theatricality and attention-seeking without the characteristic recurrent suicidal behavior and pervasive instability seen here.

She has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Borderline personality disorder.

Reasoning: The presentation (recurrent self-harm/overdose, unstable intense relationships with splitting/anger, impulsivity, chronic feelings of emptiness/loneliness, and affective instability with mood shifts lasting hours) fits DSM criteria for borderline personality disorder. Cyclothymic disorder involves more persistent, milder hypomanic and depressive symptoms over at least 2 years (not brief reactive mood swings, nor the marked impulsive self-harm and interpersonal instability seen here), so it is less likely.
